Siliceous self-pillared pentasil (SPP) zeolite catalysts with incorporated phosphorus groups were synthesized using four different percentages of P, obtaining a network of nanosheets in a house-of-cards arrangement. The catalysts were used in the dehydra-decyclization of tetrahydrofuran (THF) as biomass-derived molecule to obtain 1,3-butadiene. The presence and stability of phosphate (PO4 3-) and phosphite (PO3 3-) groups incorporated in the SPP zeolite framework was evidenced. The analysis of fresh and used catalysts by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) tests showed that 95% phosphorus in zeolite catalysts is present as orthophosphate groups and less than 5% as pyrophosphate or other polyphosphate groups. The P bonded to Si (Si-O-P, corresponding to orthophosphate groups), identified by 31 P-{29Si}- Rotational Echo Double Resonance (REDOR) -NMR analysis, are proposed as the active sites responsible for the dehydra-decyclization of THF to obtain 1,3-butadiene. The P-SPP zeolite catalyst with 0.2 ratio of precursors P and Si in the synthesis, presented the best performance. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords P-SPP Biomass-derived THF Butadiene Tetrahydrofuran REDOR NMR 1 Introduction Nowadays, an alternative and renewable source of building blocks for the chemical industry are biomass-derived molecules [1], which can proceed from organic matter of plants or animal origin, including organic waste and residues, and can be used as raw material in the production of different chemical compounds; for example, to obtain furfural directly from lignocellulosic biomass, mainly from inedible crop residues [2]. A furfural-derived compound of great interest to the scientific community is tetrahydrofuran (THF), a cyclic ether that has various applications both as solvent or reagent to obtain multiple products [3] such as 1,3-butadiene, which is itself a chemical product of great interest to the industry because of its diverse uses such as the production of synthetic rubber and as an intermediary in the manufacturing of various plastics. Recently, the production of 1,3-butadiene has been reported from different chemical reactions and using different catalysts that allow a higher yield, such as the dehydration of 1,4-butanediol [4], as well as the reaction of an ethanol and acetaldehyde mixture [5], among other biorefinery reactions, where catalysts other than mesoporous silica [6] and mixed oxide catalysts [7] have been implemented, which is why there is continuous interest in studying these routes. Abdelrahman et al. reported the biomass-derived 1,3-butadiene production by catalytic dehydra-decyclization of tetrahydrofuran (THF) [8], indicating the best catalyst was the material they called phosphorus-containing siliceous self-pillared pentasil (P-SPP, with MFI structure), exhibiting high selectivity of 85% to butadiene at an 89%conversion of THF at 400 ºC. On the other hand, Zhang et al. reported for the first time the synthesis of the SPP zeolite [9] using a precursor of tetrabutylphosphonium (TBP), obtaining a new hierarchical zeolite made of orthogonally connected microporous nanosheets with a house-of-cards arrangement; they also described good behavior with low diffusion effect in different catalytic reactions. Similarly, the synthesis of hierarchical zeolites was reviewed by Zhang et al. [10], analyzing different methods such as the use of structure-directing agents for the formation of materials with different porosities, concluding that this method meant a great advance for the design of hierarchical materials. Different works have reported catalysts with phosphorus lose catalytic activity, maybe due to the reduction of P content [11,12], change of oxidation state of oxide phosphorus species [13], or destruction of catalyst structure [14]. In this work, the main objective is to determine the role of phosphorus in the synthetic catalyst P-SPP for the dehydra-decyclization of tetrahydrofuran to produce 1,3 butadiene in order to relate the selectivity and stability of the catalyst with the content of phosphorus. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of catalyst For the synthesis of the P-SPP catalyst, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98%, Sigma Aldrich) was used as a precursor for silicon, while tetra butylphosphonium hydroxide (TBPOH, 40%, Sigma Aldrich) was used as structure-directing agent and phosphorus precursor, so its amount was varied to have different P contents; ethanol (EtOH) was used as solvent. The molar ratios were as follows: 1 SiO2: x TBPOH: 10 H2O: 4 EtOH, where x = 0.1, 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4 according to the molar ratio required to vary the phosphorus content. The methodology followed was according to the work reported by Zhang et al. [9] the synthesis of catalyst was carried out in a 3-necked flask, the TEOS was placed and the TBPOH was added dropwise, while stirring at room temperature (25 °C), deionized water was then added to carry out the hydrolysis. Afterwards, the solution was stirred for 12 h until a clear sol consistence was formed. Subsequently, it was placed in a Teflon-coated stainless steel autoclave for the hydrothermal treatment, which was carried out in a preheated oven at 120 °C for 48 h; it is at this stage of the process where rotational growth takes place, to form the characteristic house-of-cards arrangement. The obtained product was washed with deionized water, repeatedly centrifuged at 11,000 rpm for 20 min and decanted; the solid was separated from the supernatant until the pH of the supernatant was below 9. The solid obtained was dried at 70 °C for 12 h and finally the sample was dried at 550 °C to remove the template and define the crystalline structure of the P-SPP zeolite. The samples were labeled according the SiO2:TBPOH ratio of 1:0.1, 1:0.2, 1:0.3 and 1:0.4 as 0.1 TBPOH, 0.2 TBPOH, 0.3 TBPOH and 0.4 TBPOH respectively. 2.2 Characterization Characterization by X-ray Diffraction (XRD), was performed in order to determine the crystalline phases of the synthesized catalysts and a Siemens equipment, model D5000, E04–0012 series provided with Ni–filtered Cu Kα radiation was used. The samples were run under the conditions: 2 theta scale (2θ), from 5° to 90°, step size of 0.20° and step time of four seconds, at a temperature of 25 °C. The identification of the peaks in each diffractogram was carried out with the help of the Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS). The functional groups in the catalysts were identified by Fourier-Transform Infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), using a FTIR Spectrum 100 Optica Spectrophotometer, Perkin-Elmer. The analyses were performed by scanning the powders from 350 to 4000 cm−1, using an Attenuated Total Reflection (ATR) cell with 50 scans and a resolution of 4 cm−1. The images of the crystallographic structure of each sample, were obtained with High-Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM). Subsequently, a drop of a solution of some powders of catalyst in ethanol was added to a copper mesh with carbon lace, drying at room temperature for 24 h. The samples were analyzed on a FEI Titan G2 80–300 (Hillsboro, OR, USA) transmission electron microscope. In order to determine the phosphorus concentration in the catalysts, elemental analysis was carried out with Atomic Absorption Spectrophotometry (AAS), using an iCE 3000 Series II, AA Spectrometer (Thermo Scientific), operating at a wavelength of 248.3 nm and a current of 5 mA, using 100 mg of sample. Nitrogen physisorption to analyze the microstructural properties of the catalysts was performed using a Micromeritic, TriStar II Plus. First, the samples (50 mg) were degassed at 200 °C for 24 h, then the N2 isotherms were obtained at 77 K. By means of the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method, the surface area was determined; volume pore size and pore size distribution of each of the catalysts was evaluated with Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. X–ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) technique was conducted for surface-sensitive quantitative analysis of P and Si of the samples; the equipment used was K–Alpha, Thermo Scientific. The conditions of the measurements have been reported in our previous work [15]. Solid-state Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (SSNMR) spectra were recorded using a custom-built 3.2 mm 1H-X-Y triple resonance MAS probe on a 14.1 T magnet spectrometer (1H 600 MHz) that is operational by a Bruker Neo console. The Cross Polarization (CP) and Magic Angle Spinning (MAS) [16,17] 29Si (29Si-CPMAS) spectra were obtained under 1H decoupling (SPINAL-64) [18] with 100 kHz 1H pulse power. In the case of obtaining 31P spectra, it was not possible to perform1H–31P CPMAS method and therefore directly polarized 31P MAS spectra were obtained by applying a 90° pulse or a 90°- 180 ° Hahn echo pulse because phosphate groups in these samples are very flexible and/or are far away from the nearby 1Hs. The1H–29Si CP mixing time used was 2 ms and the MAS spinning rate used for measuring 29Si-CPMAS and 31P MAS spectra was 16 kHz. The connectivity of the atom from 31P to 29Si was assessed by Rotational-Echo Double-Resonance (REDOR) NMR spectroscopy [19] by detecting the echo signal of 31P while irradiating 29Si by a train of 180-degree pulses under a MAS spinning rate of 5 kHz. The pulse power used in the REDOR sequence for the 90-degree and 180-degree pulses applied along both 31P and 29Si channels were 50 kHz. The distance 31P–29Si and the flexibility of movement of the functional group in the molecule were examined by the REDOR dephasing curve, ∆S/S0 = (S0-S)/S0, as a function of the REDOR mixing time. 2.3 Continuous catalytic reactor The dehydra-decyclization reaction of tetrahydrofuran (THF) to obtain 1,3-butadiene was carried out following some conditions reported in the work by Abdelrahman et al. [8]. Fig. 1 presents the process flow diagram with some modifications in the part to introduce a glass container to stabilize the concentration of THF. A flow of 200 mL/min of nitrogen carried the THF vapors into a controlled temperature chamber; the inlet concentration of THF was maintained at 500 ± 40 ppm in volume (an average inlet partial pressure of THF of 5 *10−4 atm). The catalyst (200 mg) was placed inside a 316 stainless steel tube, ¼ inch diameter and 10 cm length, with the catalyst packed using mineral wool (top and bottom), resulting in a packing height of 1.5 cm. K-type thermocouples were used to measure the temperature at the inlet and into the reactor. To quantify the composition of inlet and outlet gases, Gas Chromatography (GC) analyzer was used, model HP5890 series II equipped with a split injector, a Flame Ionization Detector (FID) and a DB-624 of 30 m x 0.5 mm, 3.00 µm column (Agilent). All tests were performed at atmospheric pressure and steady state conditions. To identify 1,3-butadiene a standard of 1,3-butadiene at 15% and balance of N2, supplied by INFRA®, was used. The by-products could be propene, formaldehyde, water and 3-butene-1-ol, but it has been proved that the formation of butadiene is more thermodynamically favorable than the by-products [8], which were not analyzed in GC. The conversion of THF was calculated as: (1) % conversion = C THFo − C THF 100 C THFo The selectivity towards1,3-butadiene was evaluated as follows: (2) % selectivity = C Butadiene 100 C THF o − C THF Where C THFo is the inlet concentration of TFH, C THF is the outlet concentration of TFH and C Butadiene is the outlet concentration of 1,3- butadiene. In order to evaluate the internal mass-transfer limitation of catalytic pores, the effective diffusivity (D e), the Thiele modulus (ϕ), and the effectiveness factor of the pore (η), were estimated, using the next equations: (3) D e = ε τ D C (4) D c = 1 D K + 1 D AB − 1 and considering spherical particles of the catalyst charged, the Thiele modules can be estimated as follows [20]: (5) ϕ = R P 3 k ´´´ D e and the effectiveness factor of the pore is: (6) η = 1 ϕ ∙ 1 tanh 3 ϕ − 1 3 ϕ where ε is the porosity (dimensionless), τ the average tortuosity of pore (dimensionless), D c is the combined diffusivity in the pore, D K is the Knudsen diffusivity and D AB is the bulk diffusivity of THF in N2(all diffusivities in cm2/s), R p is the average radius particle (cm) and k ´ ´´ is the kinetic constant based on volume of catalyst (cm3 volume of reaction/cm3 solid-s). 3 Results 3.1 X-ray diffraction Fig. 2 shows the XRD signals of the four different synthesized P-SPP zeolite catalysts, which were compared with the pattern of an MFI-type structure, to ensure that the P-SPP zeolite is from this same family (data not shown). According to previous works, peaks in the 2θ range of 5–10° are characteristic of this type of materials, which show a single orthogonally-connected unit cell lamellas of the MFI type [9]. Also the peaks at 2θ values between 8 and 23.5° indicate MFI zeolite type purity [21]. It is clear the sample with the SiO2:TBPOH ratio of 1:0.1 (0.1 TBPOH) hardly exhibits these two signals, which means the MFI type structure was mostly not formed in the material. One case of zeolite with orthogonally-connected cell lamellas are all-silica analogue silicalite-1 with nSi/nAl of ∞ , which is built from the pentasil units [22]; the prepared catalysts in this work meet this characteristic. The phases were silicon dioxide (SiO2), as well as silicon phosphate (SiP2O7) and tetra phosphorus heptaoxide (P4O7); the patterns for each phase match with the JCPDS No. 00–042–0022, JCPDS No. 01–072–0647 and JCPDS No. 00–038–0932, respectively. It can be observed in the XRD patterns that there are peaks with intensity centered at 2θ = 6.2°, 8.8°, 15.8° and 23.1°, characteristic of SiO2, related to planes (110), (200), (202), (501) and (114), respectively. In the case of SiP2O7, the peaks at 2θ = 15.2°, 23.4°, 24.5°, 26.4°, 45.5°, 55° and 65° are characteristic of this phase, and are related to the planes (011), (110), (111), (112), (204), (216) and (143). Finally, the P4O7 phase presents peaks centered at 2θ = 17.7°, 30.8° and 36°, which are related to the planes (11–1), (13–1) and (231). These same signals have been reported in previous studies, corresponding with the phases present in each of the P-SPP zeolite samples [23,24]. Also was analyzed with the MFI 01–087–2275 JCPDS and the main peaks matched with the SiO2 phase, but the number of signals reported in the JCPDS were numerous and are not shown. It is notorious that the differences between the % of the identified phases for all samples are small, and then the non-crystalline phosphorous compounds can be detected in the next characterization results, which are more related to the difference of the catalytic properties. From the diffractograms, the 0.1 TBPOH sample appears very amorphous compared to the other samples (0.2, 0.3 and 0.4 TBPOH); this is due to the low amount of structure-directing agent added compared to the other samples, suggesting there was not enough reagent to carry out the complete synthesis of the P-SPP zeolite. In the same way, the characteristic signals of the phosphorus phases are not available, because according to previous reports, the phosphorus is bound in the framework of the zeolite through oxygen [25]. Table 1 shows the percentage of crystalline phases present in the samples (less 0.1 TBPOH), for which the highest peak areas (Fig. 1) were selected and compared, clarifying is a semi-quantitative method. Even 0.2 TBPOH, which was prepared with less quantity of phosphorus structure-directing agent, formed more relative percentage of P4O7 phase, compared with 0.3 TBPOH and 0.4 TBPOH. Since it has been reported that the acidic sites attributed to the phosphate groups incorporated in the framework of the zeolite are responsible for the increase in selectivity to form 1,3-butadiene [26,27], a better performance in the catalytic tests can be expected when 0.2 TBPOH catalyst is used; an excess in the amount of phosphorus agent may cause a misalignment of the P-SPP structure [28], although according to the XRD results, the presence of the desired structure was confirmed. It is important also to note that the SPP framework is formed by the SiO2 crystalline phase [9] and the P content could be exclusively founded in the extraframework; the IR, XPS or NMR characterization results in this same work can confirm it. 3.2 FT-IR spectra Fig. 3 presents the FT-IR spectra of the 0.2 – 0.4 TBPOH catalysts, which presented the well-formed crystal structure according to the XRD results. The wavenumber range of 1500–400 cm−1 is shown, which is where the vibrations of the functional groups of interest are observed. The first band around 1196 cm−1, corresponds to the asymmetric stretching vibration of the external tetrahedra Si-O-Si bond; this signal is present in all samples, although for 0.4 TBPOH the vibration occurs at a slightly higher wavenumber. The signal around 1068 cm−1is attributed to the vibrations of the internal Si-O-Si bonds of the tetrahedra, but it can also be associated to the P-O-P bonds [29]; it has been proven that the phosphate groups are found within the framework of the P-SPP zeolite and when there is a lower amount of phosphorus, the grafting is superior. For 0.4 TBPOH catalyst, the band shifted to higher wavenumber (1070 cm−1), which may be related to the number of P-O-P bonds within the framework of the P-SPP zeolite. On the other hand, the barely pronounced signal occurring at 955 cm−1 is found within the characteristic bands of the external O-Si-O bonds in the tetrahedra, and for the sample 0.4 TBPOH, this signal disappears. This may be associated with the phosphorus not being completely anchored inside the catalyst, remaining on the surface, and these O-Si-O bonds may be blocked by–PO(OH)2 groups [25]. The bands around 788 cm−1 correspond to the symmetrical stretching vibrations of the external O-Si-O bonds; these vibrations between 820 and 750 cm−1 are common in zeolites, and are attributed to the external bonds of the tetrahedra [30]. Finally, the signals at 542 and 426 cm−1 are attributed to the bending vibrations of the SiO4 bond [29]. The 0.4 TBPOH catalyst presents slight differences with respect to the other samples; the differences are related with the interaction of phosphorus groups with the all-silica analog silicalite material, more precisely with the framework of P-SPP zeolite; therefore, the difference in catalytic activity may be related to these punctual findings. 3.3 Physisorption of N2 Fig. 4 shows the adsorption-desorption isotherms of N2, as well as the pore size distribution of the four synthesized samples with different phosphorus content. For the 0.1 TBPOH catalyst, a type IV isotherm is observed according to the IUPAC classification [31], which is associated with mesoporous materials a steep slope can be observed in the desorption curve that begins around p/p0 = 0.75 parallel to the curve of adsorption, this behavior is due to the capillary condensation phenomenon and percolating properties of the solid, which denote the hysteresis cycle identified as type H1, attributed to mesopores with cylinder-type morphologies and very narrow pore distributions [32,33]. The samples 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4 TBPOH present H3 hysteresis type, which is characteristic of parallel plate pore agglomerates, such as piled-up clays [33]; this is consistent with a self-pillared zeolite. The behavior of the adsorption-desorption branches is different in the 0.1 TBPOH sample compared to the 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4 TBPOH samples, this difference could be attributed to the fact that there is a lower amount of structure directing agent in 0.1 TBPOH, which is the template in addition to being a precursor of phosphorus, it may not enable a complete reaction for the formation of the zeolite P-SPP [34,35]. Table 1 presents the summary of the microstructural properties for the four synthesized zeolite samples; the average pore size decrease with P content, between the 0.2, 0.3, 0.4 TBPOH catalysts (0.1 TBPOH catalyst is not into this correlation). In general, the reduction in pore size can be attributed to the fact that phosphates are connected in the framework of the zeolite forming barriers to diffusion, decreasing the formation of intermediate species and restricting the formation of isomers, for which an increase in selectivity could be ascribed to the phosphate groups connected to the framework of the zeolite [24], this behavior can be corroborated with XPS results. On the other hand, the surface area of the 0.2 TBPOH catalyst increases, then slightly decreases to 475 m2/g in 0.3 TBPOH and finally a 24% increase in the 0.4 TBPOH catalyst according to Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) theory analysis is observed. It has been shown that in zeolites synthesized with silicon, without the presence of aluminum and with varied phosphorus content, an increase in surface area occurs, which can be associated with the type of bonds that phosphorus forms in the silicon-oxygen matrix, since phosphorus is a divalent element and its electronic interaction could favor the appearance of defects or the creation of some vacancies in the network during the formation of structural agglomerates, promoting porosity [36,37]; this is reflected in the absorbed amount of nitrogen in Fig. 4. Therefore, it can be discussed that the 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4 TBPOH samples have the same pore geometry and there is an increase in the adsorption capacity with the content of phosphorus present, this increase may be attributed to the broadening of the nanosheets of the MFI structure [38–40]. 3.4 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy According to the catalytic tests, XPS analyzes were performed on the 0.2 TBPOH and 0.3 TBPOH samples, both fresh (before reaction) and used (after reaction), to determine the chemical composition and states of silicon and phosphorus on the surface. Fig. 5 presents the high resolution XPS spectra of Si 2p for the 0.2 TBPOH and 0.3 TBPOH catalysts; the characteristic signal of Si 2p is observed around 105 eV and is attributed to the SiO2 phase; normally it is present at 103.3 eV, but it may shift to a higher binding energy (BE) when an element such as phosphorus is incorporated [28,37]. In the case of fresh catalysts, the signal is located at 105.7 and 105.8 eV for the 0.2 TBPOH and 0.3 TBPOH catalysts, respectively. This small shift to a higher BE value between the samples can be related to the increase in phosphorus content [41], which although was only a decimal in percent, was enough to promote a displacement in BE as reported by other authors, who have used different concentrations of phosphorus (including up to 10%) and observed this same displacement of 1 decimal eV [37]. It has also been shown that an excess of P can cause a misalignment in the crystalline structure of the zeolite made up of Si-O-Si tetrahedral [26,42], as observed in both catalysts in this work, which indicates a good incorporation of P in the interstitial sites in the lattice, during the synthesis of the material [27,43]. In this work, P contents may have caused small changes in the crystalline structure of the zeolite which were not possible to observe by XRD; however, by XPS of Si 2p, a shift of the BE is observed [25,27]. In the case of the used catalysts (Fig. 5b and 5d), the BE signal was observed at 105.29 and 104.83 eV, for 0.2 TBPOH and 0.3 TBPOH, respectively. There is a decrease in BE for both catalysts, with a difference of 0.41 and 0.97 eV, compared to fresh catalysts, which could be related to phosphorus loss, inducing the recovery of the stability between silicon and oxygen, due to the phosphorus being bound in the framework of the zeolite [25,28]. This higher difference ΔBE for used 0.3 TBPOH compared with used 0.2 TBPOH catalyst, can be related to the instability of the formulation of 0.3 TBPOH catalyst, in this case in Si 2p signal of the trimethylsilyl group bonds; more information is provided in the NMR analyses. Fig. 6 presents the high-resolution XPS spectra of P 2p for the fresh and used 0.2 TBPOH and 0.3 TBPOH catalysts. As observed, the characteristic BE signals of P 2p between137–136 and 135–134 eV are attributed to the phosphate (PO4 3-) and phosphite (PO3 3-)groups, respectively [29]. The fresh 0.2 TBPOH catalyst (Fig. 6a) presented 4 signals, where the first two (at 137.71 and 136.53 eV) correspond to the PO4 3-2p1/2 and PO4 3-2p3/2phosphate groups [42]. On the other hand, the signals at 135.44 and 134.87 eV are attributed to PO3 3-2p1/2 and PO3 3-2p3/2 phosphite groups [29,44]. The fresh 0.3 TBPOH catalyst (Fig. 6c) showed the same signals, with a slightly higher shift in BE. The signals of the PO4 3- groups were presented at 137.73 and 136.82 eV, corresponding to P 2p1/2 and P 2p3/2, respectively. The signal for the phosphite groups occurred at 135.88 and 134.95 eV, signals attributed to P 2p1/2 and P 2p3/2, respectively. As noticed, these signals present an increase in their BE compared to 0.2 TBPOH, which was also observed for the XPS of Si and that as already mentioned could be due to the increase in phosphorus content. In the case of used catalysts, the signals presented by 0.2 TBPOH and 0.3 TBPOH are the same, with the signals between 136 and 137 and 134–135 eV attributed to phosphate groups (PO4 3-) and phosphites (PO3 3-), respectively (Fig. 6b and d). When comparing the used 0.2 TBPOH catalyst with the fresh one, that BE signals attributed to phosphates increased by 0.26 eV and 0.41 eV for the P 2p1/2 and P 2p3/2 signals, respectively, in contrast with the 0.3 TBPOH sample, which showed a decrease in BE, with a difference of 0.45 eV and 0.4 for the P 2p1/2 and P 2p3/2 signals, respectively (compared with fresh 0.3 TBPOH). This again shows the phosphate groups are better anchored in the framework of the zeolite for 0.2 TBPOH, compared with the 0.3 TBPOH. In the case of phosphite groups, the used 0.2 TBPOH catalyst showed an increase of 0.36 eV for the P 2p1/2signal, while the signal of P 2p3/2 decreased by 0.23 eV in the BE. Regarding the 0.3 TBPOH catalysts, comparing the fresh ones with those used, all the signals showed a decrease in the BE of the phosphite groups, with the first signal P 2p1/2, decreasing 0.45 eV and the corresponding signal to P 2p3/2 decreasing 0.59 eV; the 0.2 TBPOH catalyst presented strengthening in the phosphite groups after the reaction. The XPS results confirm the presence and availability of the active sites, that is, the acid sites attributed to the phosphate groups, incorporated within the framework of the zeolite in both catalysts. The phosphate groups can be interacting with the reactant (THF) during the activity tests, since the 0.2 TBPOH and 0.3 TBPOH catalysts presented a decrease of 17% and 1% in the areas of the PO4 3- signal peaks, respectively, when comparing fresh with used catalysts, as reported in Table 2. Regarding the area of the peaks attributed to the PO3 3-, these presented an increase that is equitable with the decrease in the areas of the PO4 3- (comparing fresh with used catalysts), for the used 0.2 TBPOH catalyst, it increased 17% and for the used 0.3 TBPOH catalyst it increased 1%. This may indicate that when THF interacts with the active sites (in this case with the phosphate groups, PO4 3-) available on the catalyst surface, the latter are reduced to phosphites (PO3 3-), so with increased THF interaction with the phosphate groups, a higher catalytic activity may be expected, and therefore a decrease in these phosphate groups and an increase in phosphite groups as shown in Table 2. The 0.2 TBPOH catalyst presented better catalytic activity and correlates with the above. 3.5 3.4 Transmission electron microscopy Fig. 7 presents the TEM images of the four fresh and used synthesized catalysts: 0.1 TBPOH, 0.2 TBPOH, 0.3 TBPOH and 0.4 TBPOH. The fresh 0.1 TBPOH catalyst (Fig. 7a) exhibits semispherical modular particles (SMPs) of 77 ± 9 nm diameter. The SMPs can be slightly noted to be almost entirely made up of spongy material, which is evidence of non-crystalline phase; this is in agreement with the XRD result (Fig. 2). After reaction (Fig. 7b) the SMPs sintered, and their average diameter increased to 174 ± 14 nm; the formulation of SiO2 with TBPOH at ratio of 1–0.1 appeared insufficient to achieve the synthesis of the SPP zeolite. The TEM image for fresh 0.2 TBPOH catalyst (Fig. 7c) shows a crystalline SMP, and it can be observed that is really made of the typical the nanosheets house-of-cards arrangement for SPP zeolite reported for the first time by Zhang et al. [9]. The SMP presents similar 173 and 171 nm diameters, and after reaction (Fig. 7d) the semispherical configuration was almost kept with diameters of 185 and 177 nm. It is notorious how the used 0.2 TBPH catalyst does not show sintering between SMPs and the lamellas of nanosheets maintained the orthogonal position between them. It can be as summed that the formulation of SiO2 with TBPOH at ratio of 1–0.2 produced a stable catalyst of P-SPP type zeolite. On the other hand, 0.3 TBPOH and 0.4 TBPH fresh catalysts (Fig. 7e and g) also present SMP configurations, but with lower diameters compared with the 0.2 TBPOH catalyst: 147 ± 20 nm and 129 ± 13 nm, respectively. Furthermore, the micrographs indicate some formation of the house-of-cards arrangement of the nanosheets; it is also notorious that some nanosheets are not completely in orthogonal mode between them. The excess of P addition using the TBPOH reagent in the synthesis (compared with the 0.2 TBPOH catalyst formulation) may have distorted the MFI intergrowth structure, to form the SPP zeolite and consequently to affect the hierarchical characteristic [9], and then in the reaction tests the transport of reagents can be deficient. The images of used catalysts (Fig. 7f and 7h) both show a crystalline phase deterioration along with some sintering. 3.6 Catalytic tests Fig. 8 shows the catalytic conversion of THF using the four different catalysts, as a function of temperature. The 0.1 TBPOH catalyst showed a good conversion value of 86% at the lowest temperature (250 ºC), but at the highest temperature (400 °C) the conversion decreased down to76%; although the conversion range is competitive, activity loss can be strongly related with poor stability due to low content of P-SPP zeolite phase and the sintering evidence found in the TEM image of the used catalyst, which clearly is an effect of the temperature. The 0.2 TBPOH catalysts showed the highest conversions at all temperatures, from 85% to 91%. A slight increasing behavior can be observed, from to 250–400 ºC. The 0.3 TBPOH catalyst showed a minimum value of 76% conversion at 300 ºC, which increased up to 86% at 400 ºC. TEM and XPS results showed similar pattern for the 0.2 TBPOH and 0.3 TBPOH catalysts, although the differences may explain the enhanced catalytic performance of 0.2 TBPOH; in the TEM images, the 0.2 TBPOH catalyst showed better stability in the P-SPP phase compared with the 0.3 TBPOH catalyst, while in XPS analysis the 0.2 TBPOH catalyst showed a 17% increase of the PO3 3- groups in the used catalyst compared with the 0.3 TBPOH, which only showed a 1% increase. The conversion values for the 0.4 TBPOH catalysts even were always lower than those values for 0.2 and 0.3 TBPOH, even when more phosphorus content is present. Despite it is well known the phosphate groups provide acid catalytic sites, it has also been reported they neutralize the OH acid groups at the entrance and along the interior of zeolite channels [25]; in the case of the catalysts in this work, the SiO2 framework presents weak OH acid sites, and it can be difficult that the well-anchored phosphate groups could increase the activity of THF dehydration for the 0.2 TBPOH and 0.3 TBPOH catalysts, and to a lesser degree in the 0.4 TBPOH catalyst. In the case of 0.1 TBPOH catalyst, the low amount of phosphorus precursor since the synthesis promoted a poor catalytic activity performance. Li et al. investigated the mechanism of dehydra-decyclization of THF using H-ZSM5 as catalyst and found that the predominantly rate-limiting surface reaction in the reaction network proposed was the ring opening of THF through the Brønsted acid site [45]; this implies that the adsorption of the THF molecule was vertical, through the oxygen of the furan ring, and therefore repulsion of the rest of the molecule exists. Fig. 9 shows the selectivity towards1,3-butadiene produced from the dehydra-decyclization of THF with the solid synthesized catalysts in the range of temperature from 240 to 400 ºC. The 0.1 TBPOH catalyst presents very low selectivity values, as was expected from the characterization results. The 0.2 TBPOH catalyst presented a good performance in the formation of 1,3-butadiene, with an increasing trend of selectivity from 38% to 87% in the range of temperature. The 0.3 TBPOH and 0.4 TBPOH catalysts showed similar values at 240 and 300 ºC, but as low as the 0.1 TBPOH catalyst, the 0.3 TBPOH reached around 30% selectivity at 350 and 400 ºC, the 0.4 TBPOH catalyst reached 15% and 31% at the same temperatures, respectively. It is important to denote that the 0.3 TBPOH catalyst presented almost the same conversion at 400 ºC as the 0.2 TBPOH catalyst, but its production of 1,3-butadiene was 2.8 times lower. In order to complete the discussion of performance differences of the four catalysts, the pore effectiveness factor was evaluated in order to analyze the resistance to diffusion in the pore. In this case, τ = 3, while ε = 0.45. The values of D K and D AB were calculated according to the methodology described in detail in our previous work [46]; the range of D e values were between1.35 × 10−3and 1.69 × 10−3 cm2/s. The range of catalyst diameter that was charged to the reactor, was from 250 to 425 mm (for 60 and 40 of mesh according to the ASTM), then the average radius of particle was 168 µm (1.68 *10−2 cm). The experimental data of conversion were fitted to first-order kinetic expression, and considering catalyst density of 2.05 g/cm3, the packed density of catalyst into the tubular reactor was 0.42 g/cm3, the k ´ ´´ values for 0.1 TPBOH catalyst were not calculated due toits deactivation behavior as function of temperature (Fig. 8), the k ´ ´´ values for 0.2 TPBOH catalyst were from 9 to 40 cm3 volume of reaction /cm3 solid-s, for 0.3 TPBOH catalyst were from 10 to 20 cm3 volume of reaction /cm3 solid-s and for 0.4 TPBOH catalyst were from10 to 17 cm3 volume of reaction /cm3 solid-s, the values of Thiele modulus were from 0.47 to 0.90, from 0.53 to 0.71 and from 0.51 to 0.55 for each catalyst respectively. Fig. 10 shows the values of effectiveness factor for the three catalysts. The effectiveness factor values were from 0.71 to 0.89, which can be classified into the transition zone but near to the region of no resistance to pore diffusion. Zhang et al. reported the effectiveness factor for two P-SPP zeolite catalysts (with Si/Al = 253 and Si/Al = 75) through the liquid-phase alkylation of mesitylene by benzyl alcohol reaction; they reported values of effectiveness factor of 0.80 and 0.83 for the two catalysts respectively [9]. It can be discussed that for the three catalysts evaluated in this work, some THF molecules reached the interior of the pores and particularly the 0.2 TPBOH catalyst because it presented the highest effectiveness factor values of 0.89 at 250 ºC. Fig. 11 presents the stability of conversion as function of time of the 0.2 TPBOH catalyst under continuous stream of THF in N2 at 250 C. It can be observed that at 24 h, the conversion decreased from 90% to 76%, the dashed line shows the tendency of activity loss. Although the fresh 0.2 TPBOH catalyst presented the best performance, it is important to determine how the phosphite and phosphate groups really interact with the Si framework of the zeolite. 3.7 Nuclear magnetic resonance The NMR analysis in solid state was performed on 0.2TBPOH, 0.3TBPOHand 0.4 TBPOH catalysts. The 0.1 TBPOH catalyst was not analyzed by this technique, due to the results of characterization, low selectivity towards 1,3-butadiene and its deactivation with temperature during the conversion of THF. 3.7.1 1H–29Si cross-polarization magic angle spinning(CPMAS)experiments The 1H–29Si CPMAS spectra by detecting 29Si (29Si-CPMAS) displays the Si-O-Si bonds typical of zeolites. Signals can be explained from the tetrahedra that share silica from zero to four vertices. The "Qn" are used to describe the degree of condensation of silicate units, where "Q" is standard for a silicon atom bonded to four oxygen atoms (Si-O-Si) and forming a tetrahedral structure ofSiO4. The superscript “n” indicates the degree of condensation of the tetrahedron, which shows the number of tetrahedra to which it is bonded, through vertices they share. Fig. 12 shows the 29Si -CPMAS spectra of the fresh and used modified zeolites 0.2 TBPOH, 0.3 TBPOH and 0.4 TBPOH. The fresh catalysts exhibited signals close to − 90, − 102 and − 112 ppm, which are related to the trimethylsilyl group bonds Si(OSi)2(OH)2 (Q2), Si(OSi)3(OH)(Q3), and (Si(OSi)4) (Q4) respectively [47–49]. It is important to declare CPMAS is not a quantitative method, therefore, the aforementioned results indicate that silicon bonds of the highest signal is the three tetrahedra (Q3), followed by bonds with four tetrahedra (Q4) and finally with two tetrahedra (Q2). During the synthesis of the zeolite, P atoms were incorporated, so they could be cross-linked in the silica network; this explains why the − 90, − 102, and − 112 ppm signals can be related to Si(OP)(OH)3 (Q2), Si(OSi)(OP)(OH)2 (Q3), and Si(OSi)2(OP)OH (Q4), respectively [50]. The increase in phosphorus content during this stage produced changes in the interaction of Si-O-P in the silica network. The results indicate that when the concentration of P in the zeolite is increased, the signal Q2 and Q4 decreases, but the signals in Q3 are favored, or in other words, the union of P with Si attached to three tetrahedra. It can be observed from the spectrum of 29Si-CP-MAS in the used catalysts, the relationship of these signals (Q2, Q3 and Q4) are modified after being used in the dehydra-decyclization reaction of THF. It is interesting that a decrease in Q3 signal for the used 0.2 TBPOH catalyst is not significant compared with the used 0.3 TBPOH and 0.4 TBPOH catalysts, which suggests an enhanced stability of the Q3 site for the activity of 0.2 TBPOH catalyst. According to the above, phosphorus is bonded to silica atoms through the oxygen (Si-O-P) of the zeolite P-SPP. The Si-O-P bond is bound to the OH groups on the surface of the zeolite; this availability on the surface allows it to interact with THF. 3.7.2 31P MAS spectra acquired under direct polarization Unlike the case of 29Si, 1H–31P CPMAS spectra from these samples could not be obtained, probably because the phosphate groups (or attached 1Hs) in the sample possess a large degree of freedom and/or the 1H–31P distances associated are too long. Thus, a 90° pulse or a 90°− 180° Hahn-echo pulse was applied to obtain 31P MAS spectra employing a moderately fast MAS spinning rate, ω r / 2 π = 16 kHz, to minimize the MAS spinning sidebands. Fig. 13 presents the 31PMAS NMR spectra of zeolite P-SPP, showing the directly polarized 31PMAS spectrum, the integration of the peaks site 1 and site 2, and the groups of site 1 (phosphate) and site 2 (pyrophosphate). The 31PMAS peaks thus obtained exhibit the signals of characteristic Si-O-P bonds, and because these 31P peaks were obtained by direct polarization they would be quantitative in determining the relative amount of different 31P species in the sample. The relative mobility of the molecular segments containing these phosphate groups can be estimated from the pattern of the MAS spinning sidebands of 31P NMR peaks. As the molecular segments containing these phosphate groups experience more freedom in their motion, a motionally averaged smaller value in the chemical shift anisotropy of 31P would result, and therefore, a fewer number of MAS spinning sidebands would be obtained. Because the morphologies of the samples are amorphous and there exist motions, it is not easy to fit the extracted anisotropic lineshapes to the simulated shapes that can be obtained based on an assumption that each site is rigid and crystalline. Fig. 13 presents the directly polarized 31PMAS spectra and the peak integration results of the spectra observed for the fresh and used 0.2 TBPOH, 0.3 TBPOH and 0.4 TBPOH catalysts. In the fresh catalysts a first peak 1 close to 0 ppm was observed, which may be related to the orthophosphate group (Si-O-PO3 3-) species. Furthermore, a second peak 2 close to − 13 ppm was identified, which corresponds to the molecules (Si-O-P)2O2 or (Si-O-P)3O [51–53]. All other small signals observed relate to the turns of the side bands of peak 1. The Si-O-PO3 3- group identified at peak 1 again confirms the presence of the phosphate groups identified in XPS, which may correspond to non-chemically bound phosphate species [23]. Additionally, they may be associated with the Si of the zeolite possibly by physical adsorption or through the Si-O-P bond [54]. The peak 2 at − 13 ppm may be assigned to P species of pyrophosphoric groups or other short-chain polyphosphates [55]. As observed, the NMR peak integration results are consistent with the species identified by X-ray diffraction. According to these results, 95% phosphorus in zeolite catalysts is present as species of the orthophosphate group and less than 5% as pyrophosphate or other polyphosphates. For the used catalysts, these same signals were observed at 0 ppm and − 13 ppm, apparently keeping the same relationship as the fresh catalysts. The used catalysts showed a decrease in the percentage corresponding to the phosphate groups (signal at 0 ppm) and an increase in the concentration of the groups (Si-O-P)2O2 or (Si-O-P)3O (signal at −13 ppm). It is important to declare the peak shifts are not there in the spectrum – magnified spectra were deliberately drawn shifted to the side not to be overlapped to the original spectra, and, all peaks shown in a spectrum were performed individually and intensities of the sideband peaks were added to the centerband intensities to calculate the relative amount of the site 1 and site 2. 3.7.3 31P-{29Si} Rotational Echo Double Resonance (REDOR) NMR experiment One of the objectives of this work is to determine how phosphorus is found in the P-SPP zeolite, since it is not clear whether the catalytic activity of phosphorus-modified P-SPP zeolites is due to unattached phosphate, or to the presence of different polyphosphoric groups or P sites covalently bound to the zeolite. The synthesis process and reaction conditions of the catalytic process for which it is used, defines and/or modifies the chemical structure of the P sites bonds in P-SPP [56]. Therefore, it was necessary to investigate the connectivity of the atom from 31P to29Si atom through the Si-O-P bond by using the 31P-detected rotational echo double resonance (REDOR) NMR spectroscopy with and without irradiating 29Si channel with a train of 180-degree pulses. This REDOR technique is designed to measure the dipolar interaction between two distinct heteronuclear spins [57]. Fig. 14a presents the 31P-{29Si} REDOR spectrum, while Fig. 14b and Fig. 14c show the shift of 31P–29Si REDOR, analyzed for site 1 and site 2 of catalysts 0.2 TBPOH and 0.4 TBPOH respectively. Fig. 14a shows the 31P-{29Si} REDOR pulse scheme, it was employed to encode the 31P echo signal under the irradiation of 29Si by spinning the sample rotor at νr = ωr/2π = 5 kHz. The 31P peaks obtained under this sequence would experience a decrease in their intensities due to the dipolar shift that is proportional to the strength of 31P–29Si dipolar coupling strength as well as the length of the REDOR mixing time. Under a chosen REDOR mixing time, 31P NMR spectra with (S) and without (S0) 29Si irradiation were measured separately. REDOR experiments usually involve the acquisition of two separate spin echo-trajectories: the dipole out-of-date trajectory (S) and a reference trajectory (S0) that accounts for transverse relaxation [58]. An example measured at a REDOR mixing time of 28 ms (n = 70; τr =1/νr =200 μs; νr = 5 kHz) is shown in Fig. 14c with the corresponding S, S0, and ΔSS0-S spectra of 0.2 TBPOH and 0.4 PBPOH before and after the usage of these catalysts. The resulting REDOR shift of 31P-{29Si}REDOR are presented graphically as ∆S/S0 as a function of the REDOR mixing time (Fig. 14d), to then extract the apparent distance 31P–29Si and diagnose the motional flexibility of the functional group in the molecule. Fig. 14d shows dephasing curves of the 31P-{29Si}REDOR analyzed for site 1 and site 2 of the fresh and used catalysts 0.2 TBPOH, 0.3 TBPOH and 0.4 TBPOH. The results indicate that for all catalysts the 31P signal shift was obtained as expected for fresh catalysts and demonstrating that a portion of the remaining 31P is bound to 29Si. For this, according to Fig. 14a, the distance 31P–29Si in the Si-O-P functional group was assumed to be 2.5 Å with a corresponding dipole coupling constant of 629 Hz for only one pair. A portion of Si-O-P was then assumed for site 1 and three portions Si-O-P for site 2 (Fig. 14 d). The results of the apparent dipole coupling constant for catalysts 0.2 TBPOH, 0.3 TBPOH and 0.4 TBPOH, was 25–45% for site 2 and 7–12% for site 1for both fresh and used (Fig. 14d). Because those phosphate groups found in site 2 are much less flexible than those found in site 1, as can be seen from the inset Fig. 14d, the resultant REDOR curve obtained from site 2 exhibits a larger extent of dipolar shift with a bigger apparent 31P–29Si dipolar coupling strength. It can be observed that for site 1 the apparent dipole coupling constant is greater for the catalyst 0.2 TBPOH with 12%, compared with the catalysts 0.3 TBPOH and 0.4 TBPOH, with 7%. This observation reflects the motional flexibility of the phosphate groups in the molecule decreases as the concentration of TBPOH increases from 0.2 to 0.3 or 0.4. This trend is consistent with the observation from Fig. 13 that the number and intensity of MAS spinning sidebands of the 31P MAS spectrum increased as the dynamic flexibility of the phosphate group decreased. The higher percentage of apparent dipole coupling force of site 1 showed in the 0.2 TBPOH catalyst means it has greater motion flexibility of the phosphate groups in the THF molecule compared with the other catalysts, thus being able to interact more easily with the THF molecule, which promotes a superior catalytic performance. This explains the effect of higher phosphorus concentration decreasing the flexibility of movement of these sites. Fig. 15 presents the two possible chemical structures of P in P-SPP zeolite: orthophosphate group and pyrophosphate group [56]. The active site responsible for catalytic activity is the Si-O-P group of the signal corresponding to site 1 near 0 ppm, which is representative of orthophosphate group (Si-O-PO3 3-); the signal of site 2 close to − 13 ppm corresponds to the molecules (Si-O-P)2O2 [51–53]. REDOR data can be simulated only for those initial points, as later data points at extended mixing times are influenced by many other long-range Si sites not directly connected to a 31P core under observation. It is important to say that with these analyses, an interpretation of the incorporation of phosphorus linked to the Qn species has been reached and given. 3.8 Proposal of reaction mechanism Butadiene production from THF has been studied in previous works, with high selectivity being reported when using catalyst called phosphorus-containing zeolites, particularly self-pillared pentasils (P-SPP) [8,59]. However, to the best of our knowledge, these past references do not clearly state the structure of the active site, the role of phosphorus and the mechanism of dehydra-decyclization to open the THF and produce butadiene [45]. Research has pointed to the presence of weak Brønsted acid centers, of the OH groups that are in the terminal part of the phosphate group (P-OH), which are made responsible for dehydration reactions with THF ring opening [60]. In Fig. 16, we present our mechanism proposal for the dehydration and decyclization of THF by means of the P-SPP catalysts, which involves the adsorption of THF on the OH sites of the phosphate groups (Brønsted acid site) located on the surface of the P-SSP zeolite. First, the oxygen of the THF molecule forms a hydrogen bond interaction with the H of the surface phosphate group; in order to create a formal bond, the electrons from carbon 1 migrate, leaving a weak primary carbocation and opening the THF ring. The H bond from carbon 2 then migrates to carbon 1, producing a more stable secondary carbocation, which is then attacked by the oxygen anion from the surface phosphate group, forming a surface alkoxide. An internal rearrangement then follows, and according to the Zaitsev rule hydrogen from carbon 3 bonds to the oxygen of the phosphate group, which in turn promotes the formation of the alkenol 2-buten-1-ol. The oxygen from the newly formed alkenol then attacks the hydrogen from the O–H surface phosphate group, forming a highly unstable +OH2 species which quickly leaves the molecule, triggering dehydration via a concerted E2 mechanism, and resulting in the final product butadiene. No experimental evidence is presented about the mechanism in this work. As observed from fresh and used catalysts, the highest proportion corresponds to phosphate bonds (Si-O-PO3 3-). It is interesting that the used catalysts 0.2 TBPOH, 0.3 TBPOH and 0.4 TBPOH remain stable (Fig. 13b), from the beginning of the reaction at 250 ºCup to 400 ºC with a total of 6 h of work,since they present negligible loss of the Si-O-PO3 3- groups (3.3%, 0% and 2.6% respectively) compared with the fresh catalysts. This loss may be due to leaching or dragging of these groups after the reaction. In general, the NMR spectra of 31P CPMAS show that the modified zeolite has highly dispersed and frame-bound phosphorus species, which is in turn related to the results of the characterization, such as the crystalline phases identified in XRD and the groups located on the surface by XPS. Phosphorus species, particularly the P bonded to Si (Si-O-P) that corresponds to orthophosphate group (identified by 31P-{29Si}- REDOR NMR spectrum),are the main active sites responsible for the dehydra-decyclization of THF to obtain 1,3-butadiene. The 0.2 TBPOH catalyst showed greater flexibility of movement of the phosphate groups, which in turn promotes better reaction with the THF molecule, favoring an enhanced catalytic performance compared with the other catalysts. 4 Conclusions A series of catalysts of siliceous self-pillared pentasil (SPP) zeolite with incorporated phosphorus groups presenting a network of the nanosheets in a house-of-cards arrangement were synthesized. In the reaction of dehydra-decyclization of THF to obtain 1,3-butadiene in a continuous catalytic reactor, poor resistance to diffusion in the pore was observed for the best catalyst, which was the P-SPP zeolite with 0.2 ratio of precursors P and Si in the synthesis (0.2 TBPOH). The different types of characterizations evidenced that phosphate (PO4 3-) and phosphite (PO3 3-) groups were incorporated in the framework of the P-SPP zeolite. Furthermore, by XPS it was confirmed that the 0.2 TBPOH catalyst showed the best inclusion of the phosphate groups within the lattice available as active sites to interact with the reactive THF. The REDOR NMR spectrum revealed that the role of P groups of the best catalyst was definitely the increased flexibility of movement of its phosphate groups. coredata.dc:description: Siliceous self-pillared pentasil (SPP) zeolite catalysts with incorporated phosphorus groups were synthesized using four different percentages of P, obtaining a network of nanosheets in a house-of-cards arrangement. The catalysts were used in the dehydra-decyclization of tetrahydrofuran (THF) as biomass-derived molecule to obtain 1,3-butadiene. The presence and stability of phosphate (PO4 3-) and phosphite (PO3 3-) groups incorporated in the SPP zeolite framework was evidenced. The analysis of fresh and used catalysts by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) tests showed that 95% phosphorus in zeolite catalysts is present as orthophosphate groups and less than 5% as pyrophosphate or other polyphosphate groups. The P bonded to Si (Si-O-P, corresponding to orthophosphate groups), identified by 31 P-{29Si}- Rotational Echo Double Resonance (REDOR) -NMR analysis, are proposed as the active sites responsible for the dehydra-decyclization of THF to obtain 1,3-butadiene. The P-SPP zeolite catalyst with 0.2 ratio of precursors P and Si in the synthesis, presented the best performance.

dc:creator.$: Río, David A. De Haro Del

coredata.dc:title: Siliceous self-pillared pentasil (SPP) zeolite with incorporated phosphorus groups in catalytic formation of butadiene by dehydra-decyclization of tetrahydrofuran: Study of catalyst stability by NMR and REDOR analysis
